result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt:
2:19 PM Defendant Kevin D Komatz appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Jennifer C Zima in court for State of Wisconsin.  Defendant is eligible for PD representation. Court will proceed with the option of having the matter reheard.  Officer Andrew Berg is sworn and questioned by Attorney Zima.  Testifies to employment as a police officer and K9 handler. Testifies to making a traffic stop on a vehicle. Testifies to the specifics of the interaction with the driver and passenger.  Witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom on video.  Testifies to the items located in the vehicle.  

Court finds probable cause to believe that a felony was committed and that the defendant committed it.  Court takes judicial notice of case no. 19CF8.
Arraignment scheduled for August 22, 2022 at 09:00 am.
No controlled substances without a valid prescription.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on August 10, 2022 at 02:15 pm.
Absolute sobriety No controlled substances without a valid prescription.
1:43 PM Defendant Kevin D Komatz in court, in custody.  Attorney Jennifer C Zima in court for State of Wisconsin. Defendant eligible for a public defender.
